docs.title: PulseStage
docs.text:
Open-source Q&A Platform for Town Halls and All-Hands

PulseStage helps teams capture questions, surface what matters with up-votes, and publish clear answers—then present it all live. Built as a full-stack AMA-style app with multi-team spaces and role-based controls, it's designed to increase employee engagement and organizational transparency.

docs.title: Why PulseStage?
docs.text:
• Up-vote–only questions to reduce noise and highlight priorities
  • Team-based organization for different departments or forums
  • Role-based admin & moderation (submit, review, respond, publish)
  • Presenter mode for leadership meetings and all-hands
  • Search & tags for quick discovery of related topics
  • Exports for follow-ups and accountability
  • Self-hostable with Docker (Postgres + Redis), open source (Apache-2.0)

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Get PulseStage running in under 5 minutes:

git clone https://github.com/seanmdalton/pulsestage.git
cd pulsestage
./setup.sh
docker compose up

Visit http://localhost:3000 to start using PulseStage!

For detailed setup instructions, see the Installation Guide.

docs.title: 🏢 Multi-Team Organization
docs.text:
• Organize questions by Engineering, Product, People, General teams
  • Easy team switching with question counts
  • Team management through Admin panel
  • Shareable URLs like /engineering/open or /product/answered

docs.title: ❓ Question Management
docs.text:
• Anonymous question submission with team assignment
  • Real-time search with fuzzy matching
  • Upvote system with localStorage protection
  • Full-screen viewing for long questions and answers
  • Status tracking (Open and Answered)

docs.title: 👥 Role-Based Access Control
docs.text:
• Viewer: Browse questions anonymously
  • Member: Submit and upvote questions
  • Moderator: Answer questions, tag, present (team-scoped)
  • Admin: Full access including exports and audit logs
  • Owner: Complete control including team management

docs.title: 🎨 Modern User Experience
docs.text:
• Beautiful, responsive design with dark mode
  • Real-time updates via Server-Sent Events (SSE)
  • Presentation mode optimized for large displays
  • Search results with live typing feedback
  • Profile management with favorite teams

docs.title: 🔒 Security & Compliance
docs.text:
• Comprehensive audit logging
  • Team-scoped permissions
  • Tenant isolation for multi-tenancy
  • Session-based authentication
  • Rate limiting on all endpoints

docs.title: Technology Stack
docs.text:
• Frontend: React 19, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, Vite
  • Backend: Node.js 20, Express, TypeScript
  • Database: PostgreSQL 16 with Prisma ORM
  • Cache: Redis 7 for rate limiting
  • Testing: Vitest, Playwright E2E
  • Deployment: Docker Compose

docs.title: Installation Guide
docs.text: This guide provides detailed instructions for installing PulseStage in various environments.

docs.title: Minimum Requirements
docs.text:
• CPU: 2 cores
  • RAM: 2GB
  • Disk: 10GB free space
  • OS: Linux, macOS, or Windows with WSL2

docs.title: Software Requirements
docs.text:
• Docker 20.10+ and Docker Compose 2.0+
  • Git 2.30+
  • (Optional) Node.js 20+ for local development

docs.title: Docker Compose Installation (Recommended)
docs.text: The easiest way to run PulseStage is with Docker Compose.

docs.title: 2. Configure Environment
docs.text:
./setup.sh

Or manually create .env:

cp env.example .env

Edit .env and set: - SESSION_SECRET - Random 32+ character string - ADMIN_SESSION_SECRET - Different random 32+ character string - CORS_ORIGIN - Your frontend URL (default: http://localhost:3000)

docs.title: 4. Initialize Database
docs.text: The database is automatically initialized with: - Default tenant - Sample teams - Test users

docs.title: 5. Verify Installation
docs.text:
Check all services are running:

docker compose ps

Expected output: 

NAME                IMAGE               STATUS
ama-app-api-1       ama-app-api         Up
ama-app-db-1        postgres:16-alpine  Up
ama-app-redis-1     redis:7-alpine      Up
ama-app-web-1       ama-app-web         Up

docs.title: 1. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
# Install API dependencies
cd api
npm install

# Install Web dependencies
cd ../web
npm install

docs.title: 2. Start External Services
docs.text:
# Start PostgreSQL and Redis via Docker
docker compose up db redis -d

docs.title: 4. Run Database Migrations
docs.text:
cd api
npx prisma migrate dev
npx prisma db seed

docs.title: 5. Start Development Servers
docs.text:
In separate terminals:

# Terminal 1: API server
cd api
npm run dev

# Terminal 2: Web frontend
cd web
npm run dev

docs.title: Production Deployment
docs.text: See Deployment Guide for production setup instructions.

docs.title: Port Conflicts
docs.text:
If ports 3000 or 5001 are already in use, modify docker-compose.yaml:

services:
  web:
    ports:
      - "8080:80"  # Change 3000 to 8080

  api:
    ports:
      - "5002:5001"  # Change 5001 to 5002

docs.title: Database Connection Errors
docs.text:
Check PostgreSQL is running:

docker compose logs db

Reset database if needed:

docker compose down -v
docker compose up -d

docs.title: Permission Errors
docs.text:
On Linux, you may need to fix file permissions:

sudo chown -R $USER:$USER .

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get PulseStage up and running in under 5 minutes!

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Docker and Docker Compose installed
  • Git for cloning the repository
  • At least 2GB RAM available

docs.title: 2. Run Setup Script
docs.text:
The setup script creates your environment configuration:

./setup.sh

This will: - Copy env.example to .env - Generate secure session secrets - Set up default configuration

docs.title: 3. Start the Services
docs.text:
docker compose up

This will start: - PostgreSQL database on port 5432 - Redis cache on port 6379 - API server on port 5001 - Web frontend on port 3000

docs.title: Select a Tenant
docs.text:
PulseStage supports multi-tenancy. The default tenant is available at:

http://localhost:3000/sso-test.html

docs.title: Choose a Test User
docs.text:
You'll see several test users with different roles:

  • Alice Anderson (admin@example.com) - Admin role
  • Bob Smith (bob@example.com) - Member role
  • Charlie Davis (charlie@example.com) - Member role
  • Mike Chen (mike@example.com) - Moderator of People team
  • Sarah Miller (sarah@example.com) - Moderator of Engineering team

docs.title: Submit Your First Question
docs.text:
1. Click on a user to log in
  2. Navigate to any team page
  3. Click "Submit Question"
  4. Enter your question and submit!

docs.title: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
docs.text: PulseStage implements a comprehensive RBAC system with five distinct roles and team-scoped permissions.

docs.title: Viewer
docs.text:
• Access: Read-only, anonymous access
  • Permissions:
  • Browse questions (open and answered)
  • Use search functionality
  • View team information

Use Case: Public access, unauthenticated users

docs.title: Member
docs.text:
• Access: Basic authenticated user
  • Permissions:
  • All Viewer permissions
  • Submit questions
  • Upvote questions
  • Manage profile preferences

Use Case: All employees, authenticated users

docs.title: Moderator
docs.text:
• Access: Team-scoped moderation
  • Permissions:
  • All Member permissions
  • Answer questions (in assigned teams only)
  • Add/remove tags on questions
  • Access presentation mode
  • View admin panel (limited to their teams)

Use Case: Team leads, department managers

docs.title: Admin
docs.text:
• Access: Global administrative access
  • Permissions:
  • All Moderator permissions (across all teams)
  • Create and manage teams
  • Create and manage tags
  • Access audit logs
  • Export data
  • View all questions across teams

Use Case: Platform administrators, IT team

docs.title: Owner
docs.text:
• Access: Complete system control
  • Permissions:
  • All Admin permissions
  • Manage user roles
  • System configuration

Use Case: System owners, executive admins

docs.title: Permission Matrix
docs.text: Permission Viewer Member Moderator Admin Owner View questions ✅ ✅ ✅ ✅ ✅ Submit questions ❌ ✅ ✅ ✅ ✅ Upvote questions ❌ ✅ ✅ ✅ ✅ Answer questions ❌ ❌ ✅ (team-scoped) ✅ ✅ Tag questions ❌ ❌ ✅ (team-scoped) ✅ ✅ Presentation mode ❌ ❌ ✅ (team-scoped) ✅ ✅ Create teams ❌ ❌ ❌ ✅ ✅ Manage tags ❌ ❌ ❌ ✅ ✅ View audit logs ❌ ❌ ❌ ✅ ✅ Export data ❌ ❌ ❌ ✅ ✅ Manage roles ❌ ❌ ❌ ❌ ✅

docs.title: Team Scoping
docs.text:
Moderators have team-scoped permissions, meaning:

  • They can only answer questions from teams they moderate
  • They can only tag questions in their assigned teams
  • They only see questions from their teams in the admin panel
  • Presentation mode is limited to their teams

Example: - Mike (Moderator of "People" team) can: - ✅ Answer questions in the People team - ❌ Answer questions in the Engineering team - ✅ See "Admin Panel" link when viewing People team questions - ❌ See "Admin Panel" link when viewing Engineering team questions

docs.title: Backend Enforcement
docs.text:
Permissions are enforced at the API level using middleware:

// Team-scoped permission check
app.post("/questions/:id/respond", 
  extractQuestionTeam(), 
  requirePermission('question.answer', { teamIdParam: 'teamId' }), 
  async (req, res) => {
    // Handler
  }
);

docs.title: Frontend UI
docs.text: The UI dynamically shows/hides features based on: 1. User's role in the current team 2. Current team context (which team page they're viewing)

docs.title: Audit Logging
docs.text: All permission checks (grants and denials) are logged to the audit log for compliance and security monitoring.

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
RBAC is comprehensively tested with 20+ test scenarios covering: - Team-scoped permissions - Role hierarchy - Cross-tenant isolation - Permission denials

See api/src/rbac.test.ts for implementation.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Principle of Least Privilege: Assign the minimum role needed
  2. Team Scoping: Use moderators for department-level moderation
  3. Audit Regularly: Review audit logs for suspicious activity
  4. Limit Owners: Only assign owner role to trusted administrators
